docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Questioning of Detainees Produced Little of Value The questioning of hundreds of Iraqi prisoners last fall in the interrogation center at Abu Ghraib prison yielded very little valuable intelligence. Most of the prisoners apparently were not linked to the insurgency and had been questioned already by the troops who captured them. A1 Three of the seven soldiers now charged with abuse at the Abu Ghraib prison repeatedly committed infractions and disobeyed orders in the six months leading up to the investigation, but received only the mildest of punishments. A13

docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurance premiums are expected to rise up to 10 percent this year, well below the annual increases of 14 to 18 percent in the last few years but still more than double the overall inflation rate. While the slowdown in the rate of increase will provide a bit of relief to employers and their insured workers, the rise in premiums means that the price of health care coverage will remain a burden.

headline.main: Increases In Health Care Premiums Are Slowing

docs.abstract: Health insurance premiums are expected to rise up to 10 percent this year, well below annual increases of 14 to 18 percent in last few years but still more than double overall inflation rate; United Healthcare, Aetna and Humana have already pared premium increases this year; Aetna has signaled to Wall Street analysts that its premiums are rising in range of 8 to 9 percent this year, compared with 14 percent last year; nationwide, premiums averaged $9,068 for family in 2003, up from $7,954 this year; employees' share of that 2003 figure was $2,412; out-of-pocket expenses rose; annual deductibles increased to $561, on average, from $488 in 2002, for using doctors or hospitals outside health plan's network; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Health insurance premiums are expected to rise up to 10 percent this year, well below the annual increases of 14 to 18 percent in the last few years but still more than double the overall inflation rate.      While the slowdown in the rate of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Stepping into an issue that has alarmed homeowners and led to hundreds of lawsuits and billions of dollars in insurance payments, a government panel of experts reported yesterday that toxic mold in homes did not appear to pose a serious health threat to most people. Though the experts said mold and indoor dampness were associated with respiratory problems and symptoms of asthma in certain susceptible people, they found no evidence of a link between mold and conditions like brain or neurological damage, reproductive problems and cancer. They based their conclusions on a review of hundreds of scientific papers and reports but warned that the research was limited and that more studies were needed.

headline.main: Panel Finds Mold in Buildings Is No Threat to Most People

docs.abstract: Government panel of experts reports that toxic mold in homes does not appear to pose serious health threat to most people; say that although mold and indoor dampness are associated with respiratory problems and symptoms of asthma in certain susceptible people, there is no evidence of link between mold and conditions like brain or neurological damage, reproductive problems and cancer (M)
docs.snippet: Stepping into an issue that has alarmed homeowners and led to hundreds of lawsuits and billions of dollars in insurance payments, a government panel of experts reported yesterday that toxic mold in homes did not appear to pose a serious health threat...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush came to one of Ohio's Democratic strongholds on Tuesday to highlight his administration's efforts to promote community health care plans, in a trip that the White House said was purely official but that ended with the invited audience shouting, ''Four more years!'' In a 45-minute conversation with a doctor and two patients who received extensive, life-saving treatment despite a lack of health insurance, Mr. Bush used his 17th visit to this state since becoming president to make the case that he was ensuring that ''the patient-doctor relationship is the center of health care decision-making, not Washington, D.C.''

headline.main: In Democratic Terrain, Bush Promotes Health Care Goals

docs.abstract: Pres Bush comes to one of Ohio's Democratic strongholds, Youngstown, to highlight his administration's efforts to promote community health care plans, in trip that White House says it purely official but that ends with invited audience shouting 'four more years'; Bush uses his 17th visit to Ohio since becoming president to make case that he is ensuring that 'patient-doctor relationship is the center of health care decision-making, not Washington, DC'; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Where you stand depends on where you sit.'' This saying usually applies to political issues, but it is also relevant to medicine. Consider the current controversy over the prescription of antidepressants to children, and the different reactions of British and American regulators and physicians.
docs.abstract: Recent clinical trials have suggested possible link between use of drugs classified as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, such as Paxil, Luvox and Zoloft, by children or young adults and increased risk of self-harm or suicidal thoughts; American and British medical authorities and doctors have responded differently to data with US doctors five times as likely as British doctors to prescribe antidepressants to children; Food and Drug Administration has issued warning to doctors to carefully monitor children taking SSRI's while Britian's National Health Service strongly urges doctors to avoid prescribing them at all; inherent differences in medical perspectives between nations discussed; FDA is reviewing clinical trials; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: ''Where you stand depends on where you sit.''    This saying usually applies to political issues, but it is also relevant to medicine. Consider the current controversy over the prescription of antidepressants to children, and the different reactions...

docs.lead_paragraph: They wear slip-on shoes (making it easier to get through security quickly), carry slim laptops and project harried ''don't bother me'' expressions. They think nothing of jumping from New York to Frankfurt to Moscow, and then on to Houston, Los Angeles and Beijing. Some even hop overseas for a lunch meeting. Yet few organizations or businesspeople think about the stress such grueling travel schedules inflict. Companies spend about $400 billion annually on travel costs, ''yet there is very, very little research done on this,'' said John Ivancevich, a Cullen research professor of management in the C.T. Bauer College of Business at the University of Houston, and an expert on the topic. ''Most of the work done is on how to control cost, not on stress.''

headline.main: All Stressed Out and Everywhere to Go

docs.abstract: Article on human stress associated with frequent business travel; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Machinists and aerospace workers for the Boeing Company's defense unit here approved a new contract Sunday, hours before the existing contract was to expire. The three-year deal, which takes effect Monday, was approved 1,221 to 808 by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers' District 837, a union spokesman, Thomas Pinski, said.

headline.main: Workers Agree To 3-Year Pact With Boeing

docs.abstract: International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers members approve contract accord with Boeing Co's St Louis defense unit; three-year pact, which includes wage increase and signing bonus, frees company from providing retiree health benefits for workers hired in 2005 or later (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lobbyists for the elderly, blacks and Hispanic Americans said on Sunday that they had begun a nationwide campaign to ensure that 5.5 million low-income Medicare beneficiaries receive drug discount cards, with a bonus of $1,200 in free medicine over the next 19 months. The initiative, by a coalition of 68 organizations, comes amid criticism from Democrats who say the drug card program is confusing and offers no significant savings.
docs.abstract: Nationwide campaign is launched by coalition of 68 lobbying groups for elderly, blacks and Hispanic Americans to ensure that 5.5 million low-income Medicare beneficiaries receive drug discount cards, with bonus of $1,200 in free medicine over next 19 months; Democrats say drug card program is confusing and offers no significant savings, but coalition points to $1,200 poor would get; Bush administration estimates that 7.2 million Medicare beneficiaries are eligible, but predicts that only 4.7 million will enroll (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Alberty José da Silva heard he could make money, lots of money, by selling his kidney, it seemed to him the opportunity of a lifetime. For a desperately ill 48-year-old woman in Brooklyn whose doctors had told her to get a kidney any way she could, it was. At 38, Mr. da Silva, one of 23 children of a prostitute, lives in a slum near the airport here, in a flimsy two-room shack he shares with a sister and nine other people.

headline.main: THE ORGAN TRADE: A Global Black Market; Tracking the Sale of a Kidney On a Path of Poverty and Hope

docs.abstract: Sums being offered on black market for sale of kidneys for transplant seem like fortune to people mired in poverty; in parts of Brazil where monthly wage is barely $80, giving up kidney for $6,000 represents huge opportunity--more than decade's wages; donors and recipients are linked by trafficking ring that authorities say exploits two very different needs: for money and for life itself; journey of kidney sold by Alberty Jose da Silva of Recife, Brazil, to American woman in Brooklyn, NY, by way of intermediary in Israel and surgery in South African hospital traced; final cost to recipient is $60,000; da Silva and other Brazilian kidney donors have seen their payments jeopardized when they were arrested and briefly jailed on suspicion of violating laws against trading in human organs; photos; map (L)
docs.snippet: When Alberty José da Silva heard he could make money, lots of money, by selling his kidney, it seemed to him the opportunity of a lifetime. For a desperately ill 48-year-old woman in Brooklyn whose doctors had told her to get a kidney any way she...

docs.lead_paragraph: APPARENTLY unfazed by significant increases in 2004-2005 Westchester and Putnam school budgets, residents in most districts ratified them in a vote this week. With the sole exception of Rye, the 45 districts that had put school spending on the ballot got what they asked for. Yonkers, the county's largest school district, does not vote on its budget, which is presented as part of the municipal budget .

headline.main: Most Districts Give Budgets A Green Light

docs.abstract: Residents in most of Putnam and Westchester Counties, with exception of Rye, NY, ratify 2004-5 school budgets despite significant increases; Rye rejects $53.5 million budget by vote of 1,867 to 1,107 (M)
